Improve this doc

Angular ***REMOVED***s are singletons that carry out specific tasks common to web apps, such as the $http ***REMOVED*** that provides low level access to the browser's XMLHttpRequest object.

To use an Angular ***REMOVED***, you identify it as a dependency for the dependent (a controller, or another ***REMOVED***) that depends on the ***REMOVED***. Angular's dependency injection subsystem takes care of the rest. The Angular injector subsystem is in charge of ***REMOVED*** instantiation, resolution of dependencies, and provision of dependencies to factory functions as requested.

Angular injects dependencies using "constructor" injection (the ***REMOVED*** is p***REMOVED***ed in via a factory function). Because JavaScript is a dynamically typed language, Angular's dependency injection subsystem cannot use static types to identify ***REMOVED*** dependencies. For this reason a dependent must explicitly define its dependencies by using the $inject property. For example:

    myController.$inject = ['$location'];

The Angular web framework provides a set of ***REMOVED***s for common operations. Like other core Angular variables and identifiers, the built-in ***REMOVED***s always start with $ (such as $http mentioned above). You can also create your own custom ***REMOVED***s.
